questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a metabolic disorder. Biochemical tests are performed to analyze protein structures and their carbohydrate components. The medical team needs to differentiate between glycoproteins and proteoglycans to better understand the patient’s condition. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Proteoglycans have long mucopolysaccharide chains and high carbohydrate content.

options.label: C
options.text: Glycoproteins have long mucopolysaccharide chains and higher carbohydrate content

options.label: D
options.text: Proteoglycans contain short oligosaccharide chains and lower carbohydrate content

questions.correct_answer: B. Proteoglycans have long mucopolysaccharide chains and high carbohydrate content.
questions.explanation:
Property

Glycoproteins

Proteoglycans

Carbohydrates content

Low

High

Basic difference

Oligosaccharide chain

Mucopolysaccharide chain

Charge

Not negatively charged
  • Negatively charged
  • sulfated or acetylated

Location
  • Plasma proteins
  • Cellular receptors – except albumin
  • Receptors made up of simple proteins can not be heterogenous, as simple proteins are made up of just 2- aminoacids which can be linked by peptide linkages. Lack of heterogeneity causes lack of specificity
  • ECM - extracellular matrix

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents because she is more fatigued than usual and frequently thirsty. A urinalysis reveals positive results for Benedict's test, Barfoed's test, and Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test are also positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Lactose due to pregnancy and lactation

questions.explanation:
Test

Purpose

Interpretation

Benedict's Test

Detects reducing substances in urine.

Positive indicates presence of reducing sugars, but not specific for monosaccharides.

Barfoed's Test

Differentiates between reducing monosaccharides and other sugars.

Positive indicates reducing monosaccharides (e.g., glucose, fructose, galactose).

Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase Test (GOD-POD)

Specifically tests for glucose presence.

Positive confirms glucose, supporting diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.

Seliwanoff Test

Distinguishes ketoses like fructose from aldoses like glucose.

Positive indicates fructose; observed in essential fructosuria if combined with other symptoms.

Mucic Acid Test

Identifies galactose in the urine.

Positive confirms galactose, supporting a diagnosis of classical galactosemia.

Bial's Test

Identifies pentoses in the urine.

Used for diagnosing conditions like essential pentosuria.

questions.text: A laboratory technician performs an Osazone test on a patient's urine sample and observes the formation of characteristic crystals. The results show the presence of fluffy, hedgehog-shaped crystals. Which sugar is most likely present in the urine sample?
questions.explanation:
Sugar

Crystal Shape

Notes

Lactose

(Option B)

Hedgehog or “Pincushion with pins” or “flower of touch-me-not plant”

 

Indicates lactose presence, as seen in galactosemia.

Glucose (Option A)

 

Fructose

Needle-shaped crystals arranged like a broom

Often associated with conditions like Diabetes Mellitus.

Maltose

(Option C)

 

 

Sunflower-shaped or Petal-shaped

Takes longer time to form, associated with menopausal status in women.

Sucrose

(Option D)

No crystals

Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar and does not form crystals in the Osazone test.

questions.text: What is the reagent used in Barfoed’s test to detect monosaccharides?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium carbonate, copper sulfate, and sodium citrate

options.label: B
options.text: Cupric acetate in acetic acid solution

questions.correct_answer: B. Cupric acetate in acetic acid solution

questions.text: A new mother comes to the pediatric OPD with her infant as she notices dark staining in diapers after the baby urinates. What is the possible enzyme defect here?
questions.explanation:
Enzyme

Disease

Option A) Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Tyrosinemia type I

Option B) Homogentisic acid oxidase

Alkaptonuria

Option C) Cystathionine β-synthase

Homocystinuria

Option D) Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Phenylketonuria

questions.text: A urine sample of a diabetes patient was tested to see the presence of reducing sugars in the laboratory. Initial color of solution is blue. What would be the color of the solution after the test?

A 55-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, and weight loss. The physician suspects diabetes mellitus and decides to test the patient's urine for reducing sugars using Benedict's and Fehling's solutions. Below are images of the test results. Image A: Benedict's Test Results Image B: Fehling's Test Results Based on the images provided, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Both tests indicate the absence of reducing sugars in the urine sample.

options.label: B
options.text: Both tests indicate the presence of reducing sugars in the urine sample.

options.label: C
options.text: Benedict's test indicates the presence of reducing sugars, while Fehling's test indicates their absence.

options.label: D
options.text: Benedict's test indicates the absence of reducing sugars, while Fehling's test indicates their presence.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both tests indicate the presence of reducing sugars in the urine sample.
questions.explanation:
Image A (Benedict's Test Results):

The color changes from blue to green, yellow, and red, indicating the presence of reducing substances in the urine sample.

Image B (Fehling's Test Results)

The color changes from blue to brick-red, indicating the presence of reducing substances in the urine sample.

questions.text: Which type of isomerism is exhibited by these two compounds?
questions.explanation:
Type of Isomerism

Description

Examples

Functional Isomerism

Compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural formulas, specifically due to different functional groups.

Glucose (an aldehyde) and Fructose (a ketone)

Epimerism (Option B)

Compounds differing in configuration around just one chiral carbon atom.

D-Glucose and D-Mannose are epimers because they differ at the C-2 carbon.

Enantiomerism (Option C)

Compounds that are non-superimposable mirror images, differing at all chiral centers.

L-Glucose and D-Glucose are enantiomers, being mirror images of each other

Anomerism (Option D)

Compounds differing at the anomeric carbon formed during the ring closure of carbohydrates.

α-D-Glucose and β-D-Glucose differ in configuration at the anomeric carbon (C-1)

questions.text: Xylose and arabinose are examples of?
Which type of isomerism involves two molecules that have the same molecular formula and structural formula but differ in the spatial arrangement of their groups?
Identify the type of linkage in the given Structure.
questions.explanation:
O-linked glycoproteins

(post-translation modification)
  • Carbohydrate chains are attached to the oxygen atom of serine or threonine residues.
  • Mucins: Major components of mucus, providing lubrication and protection to epithelial surfaces.
  • Glycoproteins in collagen

N-linked glycoproteins

(Option B)
  • Carbohydrate chains are attached to the nitrogen atom of asparagine residues.
  • Immunoglobulins (IgG) & Erythropoietin

GPI anchored Glycoproteins

(Option C)
  • Carbohydrates are not attached to any amino acid
  • Anchor consists of a lipid tail (phosphatidylinositol) and a glycan chain, which covalently links the protein to the membrane.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, abdominal pain, and dark-coloured urine, especially noticed in the morning. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of hemoglobinuria. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for confirming a diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
Which category of carbohydrates consists of molecules that cannot be hydrolyzed into simpler sugars?
questions.explanation:
Type

Feature

Monosaccharides

Single carbohydrate unit in them

Ex: glucose, fructose

Disaccharides

Two monosaccharide units

Ex: sucrose, maltose, isomaltose, trehalose, lactose

Oligosaccharides

3- 10 monosaccharide units

Ex: Maltotriose

Polysaccharides

More than 10 monosaccharide units

Ex: starch, cellulose, glycogen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is a distinguishing feature between Hunter syndrome and Hurler syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Hunter syndrome is associated with corneal clouding; Hurler is not.

options.label: B
options.text: Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency in iduronate-2-sulfatase; Hunter syndrome is due to a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase.

options.label: C
options.text: Both syndromes result in the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate.

options.label: D
options.text: Hunter syndrome is X-linked recessive; Hurler syndrome is autosomal recessive.

questions.correct_answer: D. Hunter syndrome is X-linked recessive; Hurler syndrome is autosomal recessive.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Hurler Syndrome (MPS I)

Hunter Syndrome (MPS II)

Deficient Enzyme

L-Iduronidase

Iduronate sulfatase

Inheritance (Option D)

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mental Retardation

Severe (MR+++)

Mild to moderate (MR+)

Corneal Opacity

Present (Corneal opacity++)

Absent (No corneal clouding)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with developmental delay, behavioural problems, and progressive mental deterioration. Physical examination reveals coarse facial features and hepatosplenomegaly, his ocular findings are normal. The paediatrician suspects a type of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS). Based on these clinical features, which kind of MPS is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Disease Name

Abbreviation

Enzyme Defective

GAG(s) Affected

Symptoms

Hurler, Scheie, Hurler-Scheie syndrome

(Option A)

MPS I

α-L-Iduronidase

Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate

Mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea

Hunter syndrome

MPS II

Iduronate sulfatase

Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate

Mental retardation

Sanfilippo syndrome A

(Option C)

MPS IIIA

Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase

Heparan sulfate

Delay in development, motor dysfunction

Sanfilippo syndrome B

MPS IIIB

α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase

Heparan sulfate

As MPS IIIA

Sanfilippo syndrome C

MPS IIIC

α-Glucosaminide N-acetyltransferase

Heparan sulfate

As MPS IIIA

Sanfilippo syndrome D

MPS IIID

N-Acetylglucosamine 6-sulfatase

Heparan sulfate

As MPS IIIA

Morquio syndrome A

(Option D)

MPS IVA

Galactosamine 6-sulfatase

Keratan sulfate, chondroitin 6-sulfate

Skeletal dysplasia, short stature

Morquio syndrome B

MPS IVB

β-Galactosidase

Keratan sulfate

Skeletal dysplasia, short stature

Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome

MPS VI

N-Acetylgalactosamine 4-sulfatase

Dermatan sulfate

Curvature of the spine, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, cardiac defects

Sly syndrome

MPS VII

β-Glucuronidase

Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate, chondroitin 4-sulfate, chondroitin 6-sulfate

Skeletal dysplasia, short stature, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea

Natowicz syndrome (Option B)

MPS IX

Hyaluronidase

Hyaluronic acid

Joint pain, short stature

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms indicative of joint issues, including pain and reduced mobility. Examination reveals that the patient's synovial fluid is lacking a key mucopolysaccharide responsible for lubrication. Which mucopolysaccharide is most likely deficient in this patient's synovial fluid?
questions.explanation:
Mucopolysaccharide

Functions

Hyaluronic Acid

(Option D)

Serves as a lubricant in joint cavities and contributes to the structure of connective tissues

Heparin

(Option A)

Acts as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inactivates thrombin and other clotting factors

Chondroitin Sulfate

(Option B)

Provides structural support to connective tissues and contributes to their resilience and elasticity

Dermatan Sulfate

(Option C)

Contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder affecting the structural integrity of their skin and blood vessels, resulting in hyperextensible skin and increased susceptibility to vascular damage. Which mucopolysaccharide is present in the skin and blood vessels, most likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Mucopolysaccharide

Primary Locations

Hyaluronic Acid (Option A)

Connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, vitreous humor

Heparin (Option B)

Liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option C)

Cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, skin

Keratan Sulfate

Cornea, cartilage

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves

questions.text: Analyse the structure of the mucopolysaccharide shown below: Which mucopolysaccharide is represented in this image?
questions.explanation:
Mucopolysaccharide (MPS)

Components

Keratan Sulfate

Galactose and N-acetylglucosamine

Heparan Sulfate (Option A)

Glucuronic acid (or iduronic acid) and N-sulfated glucosamine

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Iduronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option C)

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Hyaluronic Acid

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine

questions.text: Mucopolysaccharides are heteropolysaccharides containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Which among the following mucopolysaccharides contradicts the above statement?
questions.explanation:
Keratan sulfate

(Option A)

Repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Chondroitin sulfate

(Option B)

Repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulfate → beta-1,4 and so on.

Dermatan sulfate

(Option C)

It Contains L-iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine in beta-1, 3 linkages.

Heparin

(Option D)
  • An anticoagulant widely used
  • Repeating units of sulphated glucosamine → alpha-1, 4-L-iduronic acid → and so on
  • Iduronic acid is the oxidized form of idose.

questions.text: Which of the following is accurate about dietary fibres?

options.label: A
options.text: Insoluble fibre is fermented in the large intestine

options.label: B
options.text: Dietary fibre provides a significant source of energy

options.label: C
options.text: Soluble fibre helps lower LDL cholesterol

questions.correct_answer: C. Soluble fibre helps lower LDL cholesterol
questions.explanation:
Soluble fiber

Insoluble fiber
  • Lower LDL cholesterol levels by increasing bile acid excretion and interfering with bile acid reabsorption
  • Fermented in the large intestine to short-chain fatty acids (Option A)
  • Ex: Oats, barley, psyllium, brussel sprouts, etc
  • Adds bulk and promotes bowel movements. (Option D)
  • Passes through the digestive tract largely unchanged (Option A)
  • Ex: whole wheat, walnuts, chickpeas, etc

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly distinguishes between homoglycans and heteroglycans?

options.label: A
options.text: Homoglycans - repeated units of the same monosaccharide; Heteroglycans - two or more different types of monosaccharide units.

options.label: B
options.text: Homoglycans - used for structural purposes; Heteroglycans - energy storage.

options.label: C
options.text: Homoglycans- typically soluble in water; Heteroglycans - insoluble.

options.label: D
options.text: Homoglycans - only in plant cells; Heteroglycans - only in animal cells.

questions.correct_answer: A. Homoglycans - repeated units of the same monosaccharide; Heteroglycans - two or more different types of monosaccharide units.
questions.explanation:
Homoglycans/ homopolysaccharides

Heteroglycans/ heteropolysaccharides
  • Made of a single kind of monosaccharide unit.

(Option A)
  • Made of two or more different monosaccharides.

(Option A)
  • Used for both structural and energy storage.

(Option B)
 
  • Used for both structural and energy storage.

(Option B)
  • Variable solubility (dextran, cellulose)

(Option C)
  • Variable solubility (agar, hyaluronic acid, keratin sulphate)

(Option C)
  • Found in both plants and animals ( starch & glycogen)

(Option D)
  • Found in both plants & animals (agar & keratan sulfate)

(Option D)
  • Ex: starch, glycogen and cellulose.
  • Ex: hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence and frothy stools. It is noticed that these symptoms arise only when he consumes milk or other dairy products. Which of the following is the IOC in this situation to diagnose him?
Which of the following is non-reducing sugar?

A 28-year-old patient with a history of gastrointestinal issues is undergoing metabolic testing. The clinical team is investigating the role of different types of disaccharides in digestion and absorption. Which of the following are the constituent monosaccharides of the disaccharide lactose?
questions.explanation:
Disaccharide

Sugars present

Linkage

Maltose (Basic thumb rule)

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

alpha(1,4)

Isomaltose (Six atoms)

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

a(1,6)

Trehalose

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

a(1,1)

Sucrose

Glucose + fructose

a(1,2)

Lactose

Galactose + glucose

beta(1,4)
